captions.text: Alright, I guess I'll just try again later...
Quick, Sayed, can you diffuse it?
I would just make the timer tick faster.
I think I could be of some assistance.
He survives explosions because he's the only pilot
Turns out the mysteries don't matter so
Walt and Whitmore used to be important
Have yourself a fish biscuit. We're going to get through this.
Okay, Sayed, hand me that paperclip.
Sawyer, hand me that gum wrapper.
And try not to sleep with it or call it a funny name.
Kate, I'd ask for your help but you pretty much only find trails and create love triangles..
so you know, useless as usual.
Right! Jin and Sun, hand over that duct tape.
and forget, somewhere out there right now
Jack, you keep struggling with letting other people be in control.
You're the best. Can I just hug you?
Ok, ok, you're right. We'll hug later.
Alright looks like I've almost for this.
All I've gotta do is just take these two wires here and pull 'em apart like this and---

Well I guess I don't know
anything about diffusing bombs.
Does anyone have a plan B?

What do guys say we just skip all this and
meet up in an elaborate purgatory?
That way we can live happily ever after.
Well Jacob, perhaps you shouldn't have been so vague and explained everything to them sooner
You're not supposed to say my name!!
Good Lord, Claire. Take a shower.
So that's the reason for everything?

You know considering all we've been
through, I was sort of expecting something...
Ha, yea. Tell me about it.

The ending was great... It showed what the show was really about and 
brought it all together perfectly... It showed the all the characters 
needed the island and that it was the single most important moments of 
their lives. It left the mythology to interpretation like it always was...

The amazing thing about the ongoing series was our questioning of its 
mythology... whatever route they went with the mythology would have left 
some people disappointed so they kept it in a way that allowed everyone to 
keep questioning.﻿

comments.text:
So how did this show end, what was it all about? I've only seen couple 
first episodes from first season. And make sure to add spoiler warning on 
response for those who just want to watch it.﻿
comments.author: MsDjessa

comments.text:
+MsDjessa I don't really think this show can be explained in a few 
sentences xD So much happens, but everything is tied together. Whoever 
ended the series believing certain questions were unanswered simply did not 
pay enough attention.

Strictly on how the show ends (spoilers): Jack detonates a hydrogen bomb in 
a magnetic field area thing, which causes two parallel dimensions: one 
where the survivors crash, and another where they don't. Its later revealed 
that the one they don't crash is Purgatory. In Purgatory, Charlie has a 
near-death experience, causing him to recall his life on the island. He and 
Desmond then go and make the other survivors have similar revelations and 
group them to a Church. Realizing their connection and past life, they are 
sent to Heaven (certain people aren't there due to mistakes, however). 


On the island, everything that happened did happen. It wasn't fake. They 
crashed, there were smoke monsters and immortal beings, the Others, etc. 
The main antagonist, the Man in Black, is trying to escape to spread chaos 
and evil, but cannot due so until a human kills the Good, Jacob. He manages 
to do this, but fails to escape before a new "Jacob" (this being Hurley) is 
chosen (which is why the island had those survivors crash land, and why it 
had them return after they left). Some of the remaining survivors escape on 
a plane while Jack sacrifices himself to ensure they get off the island 
safely. He dies where he woke up in the very first episode. 


People don't like the ending because of the religious route they took, but 
my God, Science vs. Religion was one of the main themes across all 6 
seasons. They had countless religious imagery (Psalms, Mary, etc.). It 
wanted you to question what was real and what was supernatural. 


This isn't the best of explanations as I'm exclusively explaining the last 
season. The rest of the season adds a lot more lore and mystery to the 
Science and Faith the island shows through DHARMA, the Heart of the Island, 
etc.

comments.author: Letizia Minato

comments.text:
"The mysteries don't matter"
Uh, dude, they kind of do. Numbers were the old Dharma code for the hatch, 
in addition to the candidates, the giant foot was separated from the rest 
of the statue when the Black Rock crashed into the Island (reportedly a 
statue of a fertility goddess, e.g. the issues with mothers dying on the 
island). 

Walt was important because he was a candidate (I assume) initially. And in 
the prologue, Hurley and Ben go back for him, presumably to train him to be 
Hurley's "heir". Remember he was of interest to the Others because he could 
"appear where he wasn't supposed to be" and made things happen (polar bear, 
the bird). 
Widmore was the previous Leader of the Others, thus his campaign to get 
back to the Island.

I'm not sure that even the creators of this film truly understood it like 
some of the fans do.﻿

comments.author: RavenRuled

comments.text:
How Lost should have ended? At the end of Season One, while they still had 
credibility. They jumped the shark several times in the later seasons.

But no, they decided to stretch it out to six seasons, add tons of filler 
and superfluous characters with a zillion flashbacks which didn't advance 
the story in any way and pile mystery after mystery and leaving everything 
very vague so that the viewers can spend their entire weekends 
overanalysing every insignificant detail and try to find some hidden 
meaning to it. When you have milked the sheep for six seasons you have 
truly excelled commercially and if you were to apply that philosophy to 
politics God helps us all. Fortunately there's no money to be made as a 
politician.﻿

comments.author: dallasewings

comments.text:
I don't get how one can argue that the mysteries aren't important - they're 
the plot! It's a backwards narrative, so the mysteries are just missing 
pieces of the overall narrative that are restored the more the narrative 
progresses. Some seem to mistake plot holes for mysteries, and some create 
mysteries of their own where there were none. The only significant missing 
piece in the narrative is why the others needed Walt, which really came as 
a result of the production issues with the actor and a clear desire to bury 
that plot point as quickly as possible. I recommend everyone rewatch the 
series to not only appreciate what was revealed, but to also have a review 
of what seemed like a mystery and determine what actually wasn't. ﻿
comments.author: Damon242

comments.text:
+pwnsaurus How does the end nullify them? Look back on the series, how were 
any of the mysteries so vital to the main plot? The revelations added 
clarification, explanation for the why and the how, but very few ever 
really changed the direction of the story (look of it from the perspective 
of the characters, there were mysteries that they didn't know were there 
and they didn't know the resolution of, however, it they were vital to the 
journey of the characters and their story then they would have been aware. 
this isn't a murder case set of mysteries, these are world-building 
mysteries - for the audience, not for the characters). 

The plot was a non-linear narrative. The very nature of that means that 
there are going to be questions and eventually answers, simply because at 
the point that these questions arise the entire story has not yet been told 
and the audience is seeing ahead in the story. 

What exactly were you expecting? A singular, all-important answer at the 
conclusion of the series that would act in the very same way as the 
conclusion to the ending of the sixth sense? That would never be the case 
because it isn't an over-arching mystery and in even the sixth sense, that 
revelation only clarifies certain moments throughout the film, adding a 
different meaning to them, but it does not at all change the main plot of 
the film which involves the boy and don't at all play a role in the 
resolution to the story about that boy.

LOST was always a mystery show about a group of survivors after a horrific 
plane crash and their experiences both before the island and on the island. 
It is a mystery show - that is its genre, it is a story about... - that is 
its story.  

"Why do I have this key in my pocket? What is this key for? It must be 
important to my story? Oh wait, this key belongs to my car and I must have 
at some stage picked it up and put it in my pocket." Suddenly the great big 
mystery, spewing with all sorts of possibilities, is revealed and now 
suddenly mundane. Yet it built suspense because it was told in a backwards 
narrative, whereas if events were followed in order and the keys were put 
in the pocket and later on the character found them and was confused 
momentarily - there'd be no suspense, it would simply be an unnoticed 
thing. But that is what a mystery narrative is, they are either looking 
from the outside in and actively investigating (a murder plot where the 
characters are actively involved), or its a twisted narrative whereby the 
audience has to do their own homework while the characters engage in their 
own story/stories.

But to say the mysteries aren't important is ridiculous. They are the 
experience, they are the missing pieces in the story later clicked back 
into place.

Lost's sixth season provided a lot of clarification where upon rewatching 
the series a lot of events suddenly take on new meaning - much as with the 
sixth sense and its final moments, but take away those revelations and the 
fundamental story doesn't change - it remains exactly what is was before 
and your thoughts on it remain exactly what they were before you were told 
to think any differently of it.

I just don't understand how people can watch a mystery narrative and then 
dismiss the mysteries once they're revealed as not being important. They 
are part of the experience.
comments.author: Damon242

comments.text:
The mysteries have zero importance, actually. The end completely and 
utterly nullifies them. Their only purpose was to make the viewers THINK 
they mattered. If they were the plot, the whole plot was a convoluted 
illusion to make people watch the show. Which is really genius, but 
ultimately meaningless.

comments.author: Eagle's Perch

comments.text:
I always considered the show Lost a metaphor for "Get lost in this 
fucking show and don't have a clue what it's suppose to be about." That's 
how I've always seen this show. You were never meant to fully understand 
what the story is about. I found myself going "Abadeeabadeewhoohoo!" as I 
kept getting confused as fuck as to what the fuck was supposed to be 
happening. If anyone else understood it good for you. I wish I could 
have... I liked the show. That is, until it got too damn complicated. Well! 
That's it for my random comment of the day! Funny vid as always, Hishe.﻿
comments.author: Jonas Marsh (MovieBuff)

comments.text: grrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrr you are crazy﻿
comments.author: noa van vuren

comments.text:
I gave up after season 4. The first 2 seasons were some of the best TV ever 
with a slow building suspenseful mystery while giving us backgrounds into 
the characters that taught us not to judge so quickly.

Season 3 was ok but by Season 4 the story was drastically changing. The 
Others were no longer this scary antagonistic group. Most of them got 
killed in Season 4. When the French woman who had these spooky portents got 
killed I realized they were changing story and from what I hear of the 
ending it makes little sense in relationship to the beginning.﻿
comments.author: Ronin Dave

comments.text:
I feel your pain man :/ the writers strike during season 4 and half of 
season 5 moved the show in a vastly different direction unfortunately.
comments.author: Whoopi Swollberg

comments.text:
I kept watching. I do agree that the earlier seasons were better but that 
was only because the mysteries were unsolved. They had to be solved at some 
point.
comments.author: Circuit Breaker

comments.text:
You can't really judge at all the relationship of a conclusion to a story 
and the beginning of one when you have missed the 5th and 6th (and 
presumably, second half of 4th) seasons. The first three seasons are 
leisurely by comparison, trying as much as possible to fill in time in 
order to survive their 23-26 episode season lengths. The last three seasons 
are concise, consistent, and have momentum that the first three seasons 
(and less consistent) seasons had. Between the second season and first half 
of the third season, the series saw its largest drop in audience and failed 
to get nominations at the Emmys. The 4th, 5th, and 6th seasons of the show 
were all nominated for best series, which hadn't happened since the first 
season. The story did not change, it just switched gears when it was 
awarded shorter seasons of 12-16 episodes and began driving the story 
towards its conclusion rather than spinning its wheels. I would recommend 
reserving judgment until you have seen the entirety of it.
comments.author: Damon242

comments.text: Yeah... I still don't get it...uhm﻿

comments.author: BitcoinFreak

comments.text:
After the years I don't even remember how lost ended and don't understand a 
thing from the show. All the things written here just confuse me. The last 
couple of seasons I could just barely keep track of who was still alive on 
the show and the whole show just confused me. I honestly didn't even know 
that I am supposed to make any conclusions from the show. Just like I said, 
after the 3rd season I didn't understand a thing. Yet I found the show 
entertaining and somehow enjoyed something I didn't understand at all.﻿

comments.author: Moriah Evans

comments.text:
The polar bears were brought there by the Dharma Initiative as part of 
their zoological research. They were kept in cages at the hydra station, 
and at some point either escaped or were released.
